channel.title: What distro?
channel.description:
YES ANUTER WUT DISTRO UN!!!
I might get a semi-old pc from my brother, which I want to use as a personal webserver/fileserver. I'm going to use it to learn how to use the Linux shell, as a webserver for websites I made myself (learning purposes), and optionally as a computer that downloads torrents. I only need a command line, and the ability to access it from my laptop/desktop. I want an OS, and not a shitload of packages I'll never use. I'd rather install 10 packages then delete 20. A friend of mine mentioned debian once, but if I read their site correctly it comes with a shitload of packages. I might buy a external hdd aswell, so it has to support usb connections (I guess all of them do).
Tenk u!
Edit: I forgot to add that it has to be accesible from both Linux and Windows machines.

item.title: What distro?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

Also, Mopman about compatibility with mysql, etc. mysql updated yesterday, friend ran an upgrade, no problems at all.

Read full topic

item.title: What distro?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:24, topic:233685”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=308151.msg2468893#msg2468893 date=1222877638]

Strange thing about Arch is that they keep talking about how adjustable it is, yet they use pacman which only distributes binary apps.
[/quote]You use AUR for source-packages, which is also supported in pacman.

Did they change this in the last few weeks? Because when I last used Arch pacman didn’t support the AUR, you had to have a 3rd party program if you wanted seamless integration.[/quote]

pacman installs the packages after you build them from the AUR.

Mopar is correct, if you want seamless you need to install yaourt.

Read full topic

item.title: What distro?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:22, topic:233685”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=308151.msg2468792#msg2468792 date=1222867140]
Strange thing about Arch is that they keep talking about how adjustable it is, yet they use pacman which only distributes binary apps.
[/quote]You use AUR for source-packages, which is also supported in pacman.[/quote]

Did they change this in the last few weeks? Because when I last used Arch pacman didn’t support the AUR, you had to have a 3rd party program if you wanted seamless integration.

Read full topic

item.title: What distro?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

For a production server, debian stable is just that, stable. It has been around for years and it is proven, if you are using stable you can just about be guaranteed that nothing will ever break. I would use stable on a server, but on this laptop I am using testing (currently lenny).

Another reason is simply preference reasons, I love dpkg! Check out a comparison here:
http://www.moparisthebest.com/pkgmanager/

Read full topic

item.title: What distro?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:18, topic:233685”]Yeah, and when apache updates and breaks compatibility with mysql next week?

Arch breaks quite often, this is one of the problems of being bleeding edge. It’s gotten a lot better lately, but I still don’t trust it for anything important (other than my desktop, cuz uno I’m always aroudn to fix that)[/quote]I’ve never experienced any problems with that, and if something like that would happen, blame apache or mysql respectively for the problem.

Read full topic

item.title: What distro?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Yeah, and when apache updates and breaks compatibility with mysql next week?

Arch breaks quite often, this is one of the problems of being bleeding edge. It’s gotten a lot better lately, but I still don’t trust it for anything important (other than my desktop, cuz uno I’m always aroudn to fix that)

Read full topic

item.title: What distro?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:16, topic:233685”]Actually, if the webserver is going to be used in production as well as for learning, I’d go with Debian or CentOS. I love Arch, but I don’t love it enough to overlook the sheer amount of effort it is on a production machine that isn’t just a desktop. My server runs CentOS (ew redhat etc)[/quote]pacman -S xorg fluxbox gdm apache php mysql hwd hwd -Xu gdm Wat.

Read full topic

item.title: What distro?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Actually, if the webserver is going to be used in production as well as for learning, I’d go with Debian or CentOS. I love Arch, but I don’t love it enough to overlook the sheer amount of effort it is on a production machine that isn’t just a desktop. My server runs CentOS (ew redhat etc)

Read full topic
